items.title: Woman in her 80s found dead on Great Barrier Reef’s Lizard Island after failing to return to cruise ship
items.standfirst: Police say death was ‘sudden and non-suspicious’ as investigations into incident continueA woman in her 80s has been found dead after failing to board a cruise ship anchored off an island in the Great Barrier Reef.Queensland police confirmed the woman had died on Lizard Island, about 240km from Cairns. Her death was described as “sudden and non-suspicious”. Continue reading...
items.content: Police say death was ‘sudden and non-suspicious’ as investigations into incident continueA woman in her 80s has been found dead after failing to board a cruise ship anchored off an island in the Great Barrier Reef.Queensland police confirmed the woman had died on Lizard Island, about 240km from Cairns. Her death was described as “sudden and non-suspicious”. Continue reading...

items.title: Woman found dead on Queensland island after failing to board cruise ship
items.standfirst: A passenger has been found dead on an exclusive resort island on the Great Barrier Reef after failing to board a cruise ship.
items.content: A passenger has been found dead on an exclusive resort island on the Great Barrier Reef after failing to board a cruise ship.The woman in her 80s was part of Coral Expedition's cruise to Lizard Island, off the coast of Cooktown, on Saturday.The ship's crew reported her missing to authorities after she did not board the vessel later that same day.READ MORE: Queensland's puberty blocker ban overturned in landmark court battleSearch and rescue crews, who had been scouring the land and sea for her, found her dead on the island the following day. Coral Expeditions chief executive Mark Fifield offered his apology to the woman's family and said the company was working with authorities in their investigations."Coral Expeditions can confirm the tragic death of a passenger on the Coral Adventurer during an excursion to Lizard Island in Queensland," he said in a statement."While investigations into the incident are continuing, we are deeply sorry that this has occurred and are offering our full support to the woman's family."The Coral team have been in contact with the woman's family, and we will continue to offer support to them through this difficult process."We are working closely with Queensland Police and other authorities to support their investigation."The woman was on board the Coral Adventurer, a spacious cruise ship that can hold 120 guests and 46 crew members.READ MORE: Queensland Police deputy commissioner to retireQueensland Police is investigating the death, but has ruled it non-suspicious. A report is being prepared for the coroner.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: Woman found dead on Lizard Island after failing to board cruise ship
items.standfirst: A passenger has been found dead on an exclusive resort island on the Great Barrier Reef after failing to board a cruise ship.
items.content: A passenger has been found dead on an exclusive resort island on the Great Barrier Reef after failing to board a cruise ship.

ai_summary: A woman in her 80s was found dead on Lizard Island near the Great Barrier Reef.
The woman failed to board a cruise ship anchored off the island.
Queensland police confirmed the death, describing it as sudden and non-suspicious.
The island is approximately 240 kilometers from Cairns, Australia.
Investigations into the incident are currently ongoing.

clusters.title: Year 12 students told they’ve been taught wrong subject days before exam
clusters.neutral_headline: Year 12 Students Told Wrong Subject Taught Before Exam

items.title: Year 12 students told they’ve been taught wrong subject days before exam
items.standfirst: A group of Brisbane high school students have been told they have been learning the wrong subject all semester, just two days before their exam.
items.content: A group of Brisbane high school students have been told they have been learning the wrong subject all semester, just two days before their exam.

items.title: Year 12 students told they've been taught wrong subject two days before exam
items.standfirst: T he exam is tomorrow.
items.content: A group of Brisbane high school students were yesterday told they have been learning the wrong subject all semester, just two days before their exam.The Queensland education department has confirmed Year 12 Ancient History students at Brisbane State High School were taught the unit on Augustus, instead of Julius Caesar, the subject of the 2025 external exam.The mistake was discovered yesterday. READ MORE: Pauline Hanson changes party name as polling support surgesThe exam is tomorrow.The department has insisted students will not be disadvantaged. "To ensure students are not disadvantaged, the school is making a whole cohort Illness and Misadventure application for this assessment," a department spokesperson said."This will ensure consideration is given to the circumstances when student results are finalised."The students have already completed 75 per cent of their assessments.The statement said the school has provided students with an "updated resource pack" for last-minute cramming as well as a "full day of support for students on Tuesday and on Wednesday morning to run through practice exam questions and exemplars"."The department and school are deeply sorry for this mistake and are supporting students and families during this time," the spokesperson said. DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

ai_summary: Brisbane high school students learned the wrong subject all semester.

The exact subject affected was not specified in the reports.
The number of students affected was not specified in the reports.

clusters.title: Gold Coast high-rise approved over height limit
clusters.neutral_headline: Gold Coast High-Rise Approved Over Height Limit

items.title: Gold Coast high-rise approved over height limit
items.standfirst: A 43-metre tower approved for Palm Beach has reignited debate over the Gold Coast's planning rules, with the acting mayor saying height limits have been overlooked "hundreds of times".
items.content: A 43-metre tower approved for Palm Beach has reignited debate over the Gold Coast's planning rules, with the acting mayor saying height limits have been overlooked "hundreds of times".

clusters.title: Guns being stolen and stripped down to be sold on the black market
clusters.neutral_headline: Guns Stolen, Stripped Down for Black Market Sale

items.title: Guns being stolen and stripped down to be sold on the black market
items.standfirst: Almost three decades after Australia's worst-ever mass shooting, the total number of firearms in the country is the highest it has ever been but the surge in illegal guns is not due to 3D-printed weapons or black-market imports from overseas.
items.content: Almost three decades after Australia's worst-ever mass shooting, the total number of firearms in the country is the highest it has ever been but the surge in illegal guns is not due to 3D-printed weapons or black-market imports from overseas.

ai_summary: Firearms in Australia are at their highest number ever.
The surge in illegal guns is not due to 3D-printed weapons.
The increase is also not due to black-market imports.
Guns are being stolen and dismantled for sale.
The article addresses the rise of illegal firearms.

clusters.title: First NZYQ cohort member deported to Nauru under opaque deal
clusters.neutral_headline: First NZYQ Detainee Deported to Nauru

items.title: First NZYQ cohort member deported to Nauru under opaque deal
items.standfirst: Australia could end up paying the tiny island nation about $2.5 billion over three decades if the more than 350 former detainees are successfully resettled.
items.content: Australia could end up paying the tiny island nation about $2.5 billion over three decades if the more than 350 former detainees are successfully resettled.

items.title: On the dark web, predators are 'hunting in packs' to target childcare
